case_name: N. S. Mooss v. State of Kerala

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1279 of 1967 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1279 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 1st February 1965 of Kerala High Court in O.P. No. 1138 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 1st February 1965 of the Kerala High Court in O.P. No. 1138 of 1963.

facts.text: Kattayam Electric Supply Agency is the licensee for supply of electric energy in Kottayam, Kerala.

anchor.surface_text: The Kattayam Electric Supply Agency, Kottayam, is the licensee for the supply, of electric energy in Kottayam in the State of Kerala.

facts.text: N. S. Mooss is the proprietor of the licensee Kattayam Electric Supply Agency.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, N. S. Mooss, is the proprietor of the licensee,

facts.text: State of Kerala revoked the licence by order dated May 17 1963 effective from August 1, 1963 under s. 5(1)(a) of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910.

anchor.surface_text: By an order, dated May 17 1963, the State of Kerala revoked the licence with effect from August 1, 1963. The order was made under s. 5 1   a  of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910

facts.text: State of Kerala made order dated May 17 1963 under s. 5(1)(c) and 3 directing appellant to deliver undertaking to Kerala Electricity Board on or before July 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: hereinafter called the Act. On the same date, the State of Kerala made another order under s. 5   1    c  and  3  of the Act directing the appellant to. deliver the undertaking to the Kerala Electricity Board

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 challenging the two orders.

anchor.surface_text: hereinafter called the Board  on or before July 1, 1963. The appellant filed a writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the two orders.

facts.text: Kerala High Court dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has dismissed the petition. Hence this appeal.

facts.text: State Government issued notice to appellant under s. 4(3) on August 17, 1962 asking to show cause why licence should not be revoked, explanation within three months and three days.

anchor.surface_text: On August 17, 1962, the State Government issued a numberice to the appellant under s. 4  3  of the Act asking him to show cause why the licence should number be revoked. He was asked to send his explanation within three months and three days from the date of the receipt of the numberice.

facts.text: On June 21, 1962, State Government sent letter No. 11795-EL 1/61/17/P.W. to Board requesting views on revocation under s.4(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: Much before the issue of this number I ice. On June 21, 1962, the State Government sent the letter No. 11795-EL 1/61/17/P.W. to the Board. The letter states that the Government companysidered that the licence of the appellant should be revoked under s. 4 1  a  and requested the Board to companymunicate its views to the Government.

facts.text: On July 26, 1962, Board sent reply letter No. B.VII/57051/62 recommending revocation of the licence.

anchor.surface_text: On July 26, 1962 the Board sent its reply to the Government. The reply letter is No. B.VII/57051/62. The Board recommended the revocation of the licence.

facts.text: On November 5, 1962, appellant sent his explanation to the Government within three months of the notice under s.4(3).

anchor.surface_text: On November 5, 1962, Within three months of the issue of the numberice under s. 4 3 , the appellant sent his explanation to the Government.

facts.text: Government was not satisfied with the explanation and passed revocation order on May 17, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Government was number satisfied with the explanation. It passed the impugned order on,May 17, 1963 revoking the licence.

facts.text: Board's recommendation was made without considering appellant's explanation.

anchor.surface_text: These facts support Sri Sens companytention that the Boards recommendation was made without looking into the appellants explanation. Indeed. it was humanly impossible for the Board to have looked into the explanation.

facts.text: Appellant challenged orders on ground of no due consultation of Board after explanation.

anchor.surface_text: The Board endorsed the State proposal for the revocation of the licence before the explanation of the appellant reached the State. The explanation was number placed before the Board and accordingly number companysidered by the Board. So there was numberdue companysultation of the Board and the order of revocation is void.

facts.text: Point not specifically raised in writ petition but embedded in paras 6 and 22.

anchor.surface_text: it is true that the point is number specifically raised in the writ petition. But, in our view, it is embedded in paragraphs 6 and 22 of the affidavit accompanying the petition.

facts.text: Point not urged before High Court but allowed in Supreme Court as facts on record and goes to root.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that this point was number urged on behalf of the appellant in the High Court. But as the facts requisite for deciding the issue are on record, we think that we should allow the point to be raised as it goes to the root of the matter.

facts.text: On April 6, 1963, Government sent letter No. 11795-WY/61-20/PW to Board stating considered explanation, decided to revoke, enquiring willingness to purchase under s.5(b).

anchor.surface_text: On receiving the Boards letter, the Government sent another letter to the Board. It is dated April 6, 1963. The number of the letter is 11795-WY/61- 20/PW. ... The Government letter of April 6, 1963 states that the Government have companysidered the explanation furnished by the Kottayam Electric, Supply Agency

facts.text: On April 20, 1963, Board replied letter No. LAW 5705-62/20-4-63 willing to purchase undertaking effective August 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Board replied to this letter. The reply is dated April 20, 1963. The letters number is LAW 5705-62/20-4-63. The letter informs the Government that the Board was willing to purchase the undertaking with effect from August 1, 1963.

facts.text: No second consultation between Government and Board after receipt of appellant's explanation regarding revocation.

anchor.surface_text: We have little doubt in our mind that there was numbersecond companysultation between the Government and the Board after the receipt of the explanation. Had there been a second companysultation, the Board would surely have disclosed it in its companynter-affidavit.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court order, quashes notice dated 17-8-1962, revocation order dated 17-5-1963, and delivery order dated 17-5-1963.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we allow the appeal and, set aside. the order of the High Court. The petition of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution is allowed and the numberice No. 11795- EL 1/61/19 PW dated 17-8-1962, the order of revocation No. 11795/EL 1/ 1PW dated 17-5-1963 and the order No. .11795-EL 1/61-31/PW dated 17-5-1963

facts.text: Court finds order of revocation void due to lack of consultation with Board after licensee's explanation.

anchor.surface_text: We have already held that the Board was number companysulted after the explanation was received. Accordingly we are of opinion that the order is void. The companysequential order of acquisition will ipso facto fall down.
The appellant filed a writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the two orders.

issues.text: Was there due consultation of the Board under Section 4 of the Act, given that the Board endorsed the revocation before receiving and considering the licensee's explanation?

anchor.surface_text: Sri Sen, counsel for the appellant, has urged four points before us. One of these points is The Board endorsed the State proposal for the revocation of the licence before the explanation of the appellant reached the State. The explanation was not placed before the Board and accordingly not considered by the Board. So there was no due consultation of the Board and the order of revocation is void.

issues.text: Can the contention regarding lack of due consultation be raised for the first time before this Court, as it was not specifically raised in the writ petition or urged before the High Court?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the State Government and the Board have raised a preliminary objection. They point out that the argument advanced by Sri Sen was neither raised in the writ petition nor urged before the High Court. According to them, it should not be allowed to be raised in this Court.

issues.text: Does the Act obligate the Board to consider the explanation of the licensee before recommending revocation?

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to consider whether the Act obligates the Board to consider the explanation of the licensee, before recommending any action against him. Section 4, as it stood originally read The State Government may, if in its opinion the public interest so requires, revoke a licence in any of the following cases, namely

issues.text: Is the provision requiring consultation with the State Electricity Board under Section 4 mandatory or directory?

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that if the provision is mandatory, the order of revocation will be void. The object and setting of the, phrase after consulting the Board in section 4 will have to be examined for deciding whether the provision is mandatory or directory.

issues.text: Does the premature consultation render the revocation order under Section 5(1)(a) and the consequential delivery order under Sections 5(1)(c) and 5(3) void?

anchor.surface_text: We have already held that the Board was not consulted after the explanation was received. Accordingly we are of opinion that the order is void. The consequential order of acquisition will ipso facto fall down.

anchor.surface_text: We have little doubt in our mind that there was no second consultation between the Government and the Board after the receipt of the explanation. Had there been a second consultation, the Board would

arguments.claim: Telephonic consultation impossible as Board corporate body requiring collective decision authenticated by Chairman under s.13 IES Act.

anchor.surface_text: Telephonic consultation is out of question. The Board is constituted under the Indian Electricity Supply Act, 1948. It is a corporate body. It consists of at least three members.

arguments.claim: Art.320(3) directory unlike s.4 consultation which is mandatory safeguard without waiver provision.

anchor.surface_text: In Manbodhan Lal this Court held that Art 320 c of the Constitution is directory and not mandatory.

arguments.claim: Order of revocation void due to lack of post-explanation consultation; consequential delivery order falls.

anchor.surface_text: We have already held that the Board was not consulted after the explanation was received. Accordingly we are of opinion that the order is void. The consequential order of acquisition will ipso facto

holdings.text: The contention regarding lack of due consultation can be raised for the first time before the Supreme Court as the facts are on record and it goes to the root of the matter.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that this point was not urged on behalf of the appellant in the High Court. But as the facts requisite for deciding the issue are on record, we think that we should allow the point to be raised as it goes to the root of the matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point embedded in writ petition paras 6 and 22; respondents understood and controverted; facts on record; goes to root.

holdings.text: There was no second consultation between the Government and the Board after receipt of the licensee's explanation.

anchor.surface_text: We have little doubt in our mind that there was no second consultation between the Government and the Board after the receipt of the explanation. Had there been a second consultation, the Board would surely have disclosed it in its counter-affidavit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correspondence chain shows Board's recommendation pre-dated explanation; no mention of second consultation in affidavits or letters; excludes possibility.

holdings.text: Section 4 contemplates that the Board should make its recommendation only after considering the explanation of the licensee; thus consultation must be after explanation received.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from a reading of S. 4 that when the Government consults the Board on the question of revocation of a licence under s. 4, the Board is to make up its mind as to whether it should recommend 1 to revoke the licence, or 2 not to revoke the licence, or 3 to permit the licence to remain in force subject to such further terms and conditions as may be thought proper.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board must choose among revoke, not revoke, or conditions; impossible without considering explanation; textual reading of s.4.

holdings.text: The provision requiring consultation with the State Electricity Board under Section 4 is mandatory, not directory; breach voids the revocation order.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that if the provision is mandatory, the order of revocation will be void. The object and setting of the, phrase after consulting the Board in section 4 will have to be examined for deciding whether the provision is mandatory or directory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Condition precedent like public interest opinion and cls a-d; inserted as Art.19(1)(g) safeguard to prevent abuse; object and context make mandatory.

holdings.text: The revocation order under s.5(1)(a) is void due to lack of post-explanation consultation; consequential delivery order under s.5(1)(c) and s.5(3) falls ipso facto.

anchor.surface_text: We have already held that the Board was not consulted after the explanation was received. Accordingly we are of opinion that the order is void. The consequential order of acquisition will ipso facto fall down.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No consultation after explanation; mandatory provision breached; condition precedent not fulfilled.

holdings.text: Telephonic consultation with the Board is impossible as it is a corporate body requiring collective consideration and authentication under s.13 of the Electricity Supply Act.

anchor.surface_text: Telephonic consultation is out of question. The Board is constituted under the Indian Electricity Supply Act, 1948. It is a corporate body. It consists of at least three members.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board has multiple expert members; decisions authenticated by Chairman; cannot be done telephonically.

holdings.text: Consultation with Board under s.4 is mandatory unlike Art.320(3) which is directory.

anchor.surface_text: In Manbodhan Lal this Court held that Art 320 c of the Constitution is directory and not mandatory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished: no waiver provision; inserted as licensee safeguard; object/context differ.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; notice dated 17-8-1962, revocation order dated 17-5-1963, and delivery order dated 17-5-1963 quashed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we allow the appeal and, set aside. the order of the High Court. The petition of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution is allowed and the notice No. 11795- EL 1/61/19 PW dated 17-8-1962, the order of revocation No. 11795/EL 1/ 1PW dated 17-5-1963 and the order No. .11795-EL 1/61-31/PW dated 17-5-1963

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on voidness due to lack of consultation.

anchor.surface_text: Hubli Electricity Company v. The Province of Bombay. .  The Privy Council held that in s. 4 1   a  the opinion of the Government A.I.R. 1949 P.C. 136. was number subject to any objective tests. The Privy Council said The language leaves numberroom for the relevance of a judicial examination as to the sufficiency of the grounds on which the Government acted in forming an opinion.

precedents.case_name: Hubli Electricity Company v Province of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: opinion of the Government under s.4(1)(a) not subject to objective tests but must relate to something required under the Act
precedents.cited_holding: language leaves no room for judicial examination of sufficiency of grounds; revocation invalid if not relating to Act requirement

precedents.citation: Dr. N. B. Khare V. The State of Delhi 1 ... 7 1950 S.C.R. 519.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Dr. N. B. Khare V. The State of Delhi 1  held that if an Act, which imposes restrictions on the rights specified in Art. 19, does number provide for a reasonable, hearing to the party affected, the restriction companyld number be said to be reasonable in certain circumstances.

precedents.case_name: Dr NB Khare v State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Act imposing restrictions on Art.19 rights without reasonable hearing may not be reasonable

anchor.surface_text: State of Bombay v.D. A. Korgaonkar 2  have followed Manbodhan Lal Srivastava  supra . In Manbodhan Lal this Court held that Art 320 c  of the Constitution is directory and number mandatory. A Government employee was dismissed from service after companyplying with the provisions of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we allow the appeal and, set aside. the order of the High Court. The petition of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution is allowed and the numberice No. 11795- EL 1/61/19 PW dated 17-8-1962, the order of revocation No. 11795/EL 1/ 1PW dated 17-5-1963 and the order No. .11795-EL 1/61-31/PW dated 17-5-1963 directing the appellant to hand over the Undertaking to the Board are quashed.

No costs to appellant in this Court or High Court

anchor.surface_text: It is true that this point was not urged on behalf of the appellant in the High Court. But as the facts requisite for deciding the issue are on record, we think that we should allow the point to be raised as it goes to the root of the matter.

In the result, we allow the appeal and, set aside. the order of the High Court. The petition of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution is allowed and the numberice No. 11795- EL 1/61/19 PW dated 17-8-1962, the order of revocation No. 11795/EL 1/ 1PW dated 17-5-1963 and the order No. .11795-EL 1/61-31/PW dated 17-5-1963 directing the appellant to hand over the Undertaking to the Board are quashed.

anchor.surface_text: We have little doubt in our mind that there was no second consultation between the Government and the Board after the receipt of the explanation. Had there been a second consultation, the Board would surely have disclosed it in its counter-affidavit.

In the result, we allow the appeal and, set aside. the order of the High Court. The petition of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution is allowed and the numberice No. 11795- EL 1/61/19 PW dated 17-8-1962, the order of revocation No. 11795/EL 1/ 1PW dated 17-5-1963 and the order No. .11795-EL 1/61-31/PW dated 17-5-1963 directing the appellant to hand over the Undertaking to the Board are quashed.

edges.explanation: Holding that Section 4 requires Board recommendation after considering explanation directly addresses the obligation issue.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from a reading of S. 4 that when the Government consults the Board on the question of revocation of a licence under s. 4, the Board is to make up its mind as to whether it should recommend 1 to revoke the licence, or 2 not to revoke the licence, or 3 to permit the licence to remain in force subject to such further terms and conditions as may be thought proper.

In the result, we allow the appeal and, set aside. the order of the High Court. The petition of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution is allowed and the numberice No. 11795- EL 1/61/19 PW dated 17-8-1962, the order of revocation No. 11795/EL 1/ 1PW dated 17-5-1963 and the order No. .11795-EL 1/61-31/PW dated 17-5-1963 directing the appellant to hand over the Undertaking to the Board are quashed.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that if the provision is mandatory, the order of revocation will be void. The object and setting of the, phrase after consulting the Board in section 4 will have to be examined for deciding whether the provision is mandatory or directory.

In the result, we allow the appeal and, set aside. the order of the High Court. The petition of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution is allowed and the numberice No. 11795- EL 1/61/19 PW dated 17-8-1962, the order of revocation No. 11795/EL 1/ 1PW dated 17-5-1963 and the order No. .11795-EL 1/61-31/PW dated 17-5-1963 directing the appellant to hand over the Undertaking to the Board are quashed.

anchor.surface_text: We have already held that the Board was not consulted after the explanation was received. Accordingly we are of opinion that the order is void. The consequential order of acquisition will ipso facto fall down.

In the result, we allow the appeal and, set aside. the order of the High Court. The petition of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution is allowed and the numberice No. 11795- EL 1/61/19 PW dated 17-8-1962, the order of revocation No. 11795/EL 1/ 1PW dated 17-5-1963 and the order No. .11795-EL 1/61-31/PW dated 17-5-1963 directing the appellant to hand over the Undertaking to the Board are quashed.

In the result, we allow the appeal and, set aside. the order of the High Court. The petition of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution is allowed and the numberice No. 11795- EL 1/61/19 PW dated 17-8-1962, the order of revocation No. 11795/EL 1/ 1PW dated 17-5-1963 and the order No. .11795-EL 1/61-31/PW dated 17-5-1963 directing the appellant to hand over the Undertaking to the Board are quashed.

In the result, we allow the appeal and, set aside. the order of the High Court. The petition of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution is allowed and the numberice No. 11795- EL 1/61/19 PW dated 17-8-1962, the order of revocation No. 11795/EL 1/ 1PW dated 17-5-1963 and the order No. .11795-EL 1/61-31/PW dated 17-5-1963 directing the appellant to hand over the Undertaking to the Board are quashed.
